articles.title: Game and Fish predicts fall North Dakota duck flight similar to 2024
articles.author: The Dickinson Press
articles.summary: North Dakota's fall duck flight is expected to be similar to last year despite a 28% increase in duck brood numbers. Spring started off dry, with winter bringing below-average snowfall and above-average temperatures in March, according to migratory game bird management.

articles.title: epaselect EGYPT CONSTRUCTION COASTAL PROTECTION
articles.author: ASE
articles.summary: Egypt's prime minister announced new coastal protection projects in Alexandria. The projects include the construction of seawalls and breakwaters along the Alexandria Corniche, as well as initiatives to reinforce the coastline and protect vital infrastructure. The coastal areas are at risk of flooding and erosion due to rising sea levels.

articles.title: Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia face medium risk of severe haze
articles.summary: Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia face a moderate risk of a severe transboundary haze occurrence for the remainder of the year, according to an assessment released yesterday by the Singapore Institute of International Affairs. The report points towards a surge in hotspots and smoke haze across parts of Sumatra in mid-July this year. Economic and policy shifts could inadvertently drive deforestation and increase haze risk.

articles.title: Hot weather drying out Nova Scotia crops
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Hot, dry weather is causing problems for some Nova Scotia crops, especially in the summertime.    "It's very hot and dry in Nova Scotia. It's very dry in the north of Nova Scotia."  "There's a risk of damage to the crops.

articles.title: Urgent Alert: Massive Storm Set to Impact Millions in Australia
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, and Perth are under threat from climate change, according to a new study. The study found that climate change could bring more damaging hailstorms as the globe heats up. Australian building standards don't include hail resistance, so many properties are vulnerable.

articles.title: Heat warnings span B.C. Interior, southern areas to see temperatures up to 37 C
articles.author: Moosejaw Today
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued heat warnings for a swath of British Columbia's Interior stretching from Grand Forks near the U.S. border to areas north of Prince George. The heat is expected to arrive with the end of the day.

articles.title: Game and Fish predicts fall North Dakota duck flight similar to 2024
articles.author: Brad Dokken
articles.summary: There was a 28% increase in duck brood numbers in North Dakota. The fall flight forecast is based on data from the May breeding duck survey and the July duck brood survey. Blue-winged teal and mallards were the most common broods recorded. The July survey numbers were down 2% from the average since 1965.

articles.title: Call for action as huge storm change to hit millions of Aussies
articles.author: Adam Vidler7:46am
articles.summary: Sydney, Canberra, Melbourne, and Perth are in the firing line of climate change. The larger a hailstone is, the more damage it can cause. Hailstorms were responsible for more than 20 per cent of insured losses in Australia from 1967 to 2023. The East Coast from Brisbane to Sydney is most vulnerable.

articles.title: Environment Canada issues heat warnings for much of B.C. Interior
articles.author: Simon Little
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued heat warnings for a large portion of the British Columbia Interior. The Okanagan Valley, Fraser Canyon, South Thompson, Boundary and West Kootenay regions are affected. The North Thompson, 100 Mile, Cariboo, Prince are also affected. Overnight lows are expected to be near 18 C.

articles.title: EGYPT CONSTRUCTION COASTAL PROTECTION
articles.author: ASE
articles.summary: Egypt's prime minister announced new coastal protection projects in Alexandria aimed at preventing the city from flooding and erosion sinking due to rising sea levels. The projects include the construction of seawalls and breakwaters along the Alexandria Corniche and initiatives to reinforce the coastline and protect vital infrastructure.

articles.title: UN calls for increased climate action from Australia
articles.summary: Executive Secretary of UN Climate Change Simon Stiell warns Australia could let the world overheat if a more ambitious emissions target is not met. He claims Australia could face a $6.8 trillion GDP loss through mega droughts by 2050. Mr stiell will meet with Energy Minister Chris Bowen today.

articles.title: Heat warnings span B.C. Interior, southern areas to see temperatures up to 37 C
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued heat warnings for much of British Columbia's Interior. The warnings stretch from Grand Forks near the U.S. border to areas north of Prince George. People cool off in Lynn Creek in North Vancouver on Thursday, July 6, 2023.

articles.title: Pelican Point residents build seawalls despite scepticism of rising sea-level threat
articles.author: Eugene Boisvert
articles.summary: Pelican Point in South Australia is at risk of flooding and erosion due to climate change. Almost all of the houses in the town that face directly onto the ocean now have home-made sea walls in front of them. Council and Coast Protection Board abandoned legal action against property owners who built sea walls decades ago.

articles.title: As US climate data-gathering is gutted, Australian forecasting is now at real risk
articles.author: Andrew B. Watkins
articles.summary: This year Australia has experienced record-breaking floods, tropical cyclones, heatwaves on land and in the ocean, drought, coral bleaching, coastal erosion and devastating algal blooms. Over the past five years, insured losses from extreme events have risen to A$4.5 billion annually. Key US scientific institutions and monitoring programs are facing deep cuts under the Trump administration. Australia can no longer rely on US data and expertise.

articles.title: Ottawa, B.C. provide $77M to bring high-speed internet to nearly 7,000 households
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Heat Warning from MON 6:40 PM EDT until WED 12:00 AM EDT. articles.title: "Are Loons on Thin Ice with Climate Change?" presentation set for July 31 -
articles.author: Community News Reports
articles.summary: Are Loons on Thin Ice with Climate Change? is scheduled for Thursday, July 31 at 7 p.m. at the Adirondack History Museum. Denise Silfee, Director of Education and Communications at the Saranac Lake-based Loon Center will be the featured speaker. The presentation is free to members of the museum and $8 for non-members.

articles.title: Peru's coastal guano birds decline over 75%, facing crisis
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Temperatures soared past 40 degrees Celsius (104°F) in the west on Friday. Greece is experiencing its third and longest heatwave of the summer. Shipyard workers in Perama, a town 16 km (10 miles) from Athens, halted operations for five hours on Friday due to the heat.

articles.title: ‘Perverse outcomes': NSW a deforestation hotspot on par with Indonesia
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Land-clearing in NSW surged by 40 per cent in 2023. 66,498 hectares of the state's native vegetation were destroyed in that year. This is the equivalent of 237 Sydney CBDs or four times the size of Royal National Park. It is on par with the amount of forest cleared every year for palm oil in Indonesia.

articles.title: Potential Alberta separation referendum question referred to judge for approval
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Heat Warning from MON 6:40 PM EDT until WED 12:00 AM EDT. Alberta flag flaps in the breeze with Mt. Kidd in the background in Kananaskis, Alta., on Monday, June 2, 2025. JMC flag wire: true flag sponsored: false.

articles.title: Scientists Are Worried About A Collapse Of This Atlantic Ocean Current: Here's Why
articles.author: BGR
articles.summary: Changes in the global ocean current pattern are ringing alarm bells. Climate change is likely to be to blame for this change, according to the scientists.       .   for climate change.  For confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Helene: Idled bills – promises too? – in 44th week of recovery
articles.author: Alan Wooten
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene caused an estimated $60 billion in damages in Western North Carolina. President Donald Trump and Gov. Josh Stein are working to help the state and federal levels to help with the damages caused by Hurricane Helene.    .

articles.title: Maine farmers assess climate risks as USDA cuts conservation funding
articles.author: Kathryn Carley
articles.summary: Maine farmers are benefiting from free climate risk assessments as federal funds for conservation efforts decline. The Trump administration canceled the Climate Smart Commodities Program, a multibillion-dollar effort to improve climate-friendly farming practices under the Department of Agriculture. The Natural Resources Conservation Service has lost more than 20% of its staff.

articles.title: Marine Heatwaves Surge to Record Levels in 2023
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: 2023 saw an unprecedented surge in marine heatwaves (MHWs) across the globe. The North Atlantic experienced a particularly intense and prolonged MHW in 2023. This event had several cascading effects, including coral bleaching, mass die-offs of marine invertebrates, and harmful algal blooms. MHWs contributed to the intensification of the El Niño event.

articles.title: These Are The "New Seasons" Scientists Think Are Emerging Because Of Climate Change
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: The traditional framework of 'seasons' no longer makes sense in our everyday experience. This is the new idea proposed by geographers at the University of York and London School of Economics in the UK, who believe that planet Earth is undergoing rapid change and that seasons no longer make sense.

articles.title: Tinubu Laments Incidences Of Flood Disaster, Boat Mishaps
articles.author: Boma Achenimie
articles.summary: President Bola Tinubu mourns the loss of lives in the recent flood disaster in Yola, Adamawa State and the boat mishap in Guni village, Niger State. He has mandated immediate and comprehensive rescue and relief efforts by the National Emergency Response Centre and NEMA, in collaboration with Adamawa and Niger State authorities.

articles.title: Scientists discover two alarming new seasons on Earth that return every year
articles.author: OSHEEN YADAV
articles.summary: Haze and trash seasons are recurring every year and pose serious threats to public health, marine life, and global ecosystems. In Bali, monsoon winds carry huge volumes of plastic waste ashore, burying beaches under piles of garbage. In alpine regions like the Andes and the Rocky Mountains, the winter sports season is collapsing due to lack of snow. Seabirds have stopped returning to breed at their usual time, and spring and summer are falling out of sync.

articles.title: Scientists discover Earth has two new seasons
articles.author: OSHEEN YADAV
articles.summary: Haze and trash seasons are recurring every year and pose serious threats to public health, marine life, and global ecosystems. California's wildfire season now extends well into December, while in Bali, a different kind of season unfolds each year from December to March. In alpine regions like the Andes and Rocky Mountains, the once-predictable winter sports season is collapsing due to a severe lack of snow.

articles.title: Scientists Are Worried About A Collapse Of This Atlantic Ocean Current: Here's Why
articles.author: Talia Roepel
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, also known as the AMOC, is in danger of collapsing. Global warming is disrupting the way the currents flow due to melting ice caps and glaciers. If it collapsed, European cities would get colder by up to 27 degrees within a few decades and the Southern Hemisphere would get warmer.

articles.title: Britons! Why get AC when you can just smear yoghurt all over your windows?
articles.author: Rob Beschizza
articles.summary: Yogurt applied to the outside of windows could lower the temperature, according to Dr Ben Roberts, a senior lecturer in healthy buildings at Loughborough University, who recommends it to Brits sweltering through the heatwave.

articles.title: Around 720 Million Years Ago, Our Planet Turned Into A Snowball Earth – Is This Why?
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: Earth plunged into one of the most extreme climate events 720 million years ago. The planet became a giant snowball encased in ice from pole to pole for millions of years. The exact cause of the deep freeze has long divided researchers, but a few tens of millions of millions years ago Earth was covered in ice.

articles.title: Progressives Clash With Climate Activists as New Flood Rule Would Negatively Impact Affordable Housing Mandates
articles.author: Breaking Local News Report
articles.summary: The NJ Protecting Against Climate Threats (PACT) Resilient Environments and Landscapes (REAL) proposal aims to overhaul the state's land-use regulations. The proposal was a focal point of discussion during the 2025 New Jersey Planning & Redevelopment Conference on June 13. Experts warned of the climate threats facing the state, including chronic flooding projected to affect 62,000 coastal homes by 2050. Governor Phil Murphy will decide whether to finalize the proposal.

articles.title: Ghana Secures US$70 Million for Northern Climate Resilience
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: The Green Climate Fund has approved $120 million for climate adaptation projects in Ghana, Maldives, and Mauritania. Ghana will receive $70 million to bolster resilience in its northern regions. The Maldives will get $25 million to combat sea-level rise and extreme weather. Mauritania's $33 million allocation will restore ecosystems and stabilize sand dunes.

articles.title: Turkey Sets New All-Time Heat Record
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: Turkey has broken its all-time heat record with a temperature of 122.9 degrees Fahrenheit, or 50.5 degrees Celsius. The previous record was 121.1 degrees F, or 49.5 C, set last August in Silopi. Hospitals across the country are seeing increased cases of dehydration, heatstroke and foodborne illnesses.

articles.title: Benin - African Development Bank Approves Over $30 Million to Protect Farmers From Climate Shocks and Food Insecurity
articles.summary: The Board of Directors of the African Development Bank Group has approved $30.25 million in financing for a pioneering initiative to bolster climate resilience and safeguard agricultural livelihoods in Benin. The initiative will protect 150,000 smallholder farmers against climate shocks in a country where agriculture employs seven out of ten people. The departments of Alibori and Atakora are particularly vulnerable, with one in four farmers experiencing food insecurity, well above the national average.

articles.title: Another heat and humidity warning
articles.summary: The hot and humid weather has returned. CTV's Alexandra Pinto tells us how long it will last and how to keep an eye on the weather in Kitchener-Watkinsville.    i.e. how long will it last?

articles.title: These Are The "New Seasons" Scientists Think Are Emerging Because Of Climate Change
articles.author: Tom Hale
articles.summary: Geographers at the University of York and London School of Economics propose a new concept of 'seasons' in the Anthropocene. They argue that human-driven climate change is altering Earth's annual rhythms so significantly that the traditional definition of the seasons no longer makes sense. They propose four new types of seasons.

articles.title: Is Earth Forming New Man-Made Seasons?
articles.author: Ashley Fike
articles.summary: Earth is developing new seasons, built not by planetary tilt or natural rhythms, but by human activity. In Southeast Asia, there's now a predictable few weeks each year when the sky turns into a smoke-filled haze. In Bali, the ocean coughs up tons of plastic every November through March. Breeding seasons for seabirds in northern England have collapsed, Alpine winters are getting warm and unreliable, and ski seasons are melting off the map.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Oh noes! WMO report documents spiralling weather and climate impacts', By Anthony Watts
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: WMO report documents spiralling weather and climate impacts. Global mean near-surface temperature is 1.55 °C above the 1850-1900 average. It is the warmest year in the 175-year observational record. Global average temperature is between 1.34 and 1.41 °C compared to 1850- 1900 baseline. The three lowest Antarctic ice extents on record were in the past three years. The rate of sea level rise has doubled since satellite measurements began.

articles.title: UN climate chief urges Australia to boost emissions targets
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Listening to articles is free for open-access content. Access to Herald Premium articles require a Premium subscription. UN climate chief urges Australia to act as emissions plan deadline looms. The deadline is on November 30th. The text-to-speech option is available for premium subscribers.

articles.title: Taiwan's average temperatures hit record high last year
articles.author: Staff writer
articles.summary: Taiwan's average temperature last year reached 24.6°C, 0.7°C above the historical norm. Central Weather Administration attributed the high temperature to global warming and El Nino. Hsinchu County, Taichung, Nantou County's Sun Moon Lake, Tainan, and Taitung County's Chenggong (成功) and Dawu (大武) townships set temperature records. Taipei recorded 63 hot days, the most in the country and 20 more than the 30-year average.

articles.title: Barnaby Joyce wants Australia to abandon net zero—but his four central claims don't stack up
articles.author: Ella Vines
articles.summary: Barnaby Joyce and Michael McCormack want to repeal Australia's net zero emissions target by 2050. Opposition Leader Sussan Ley convenes a working group to set a way forward on climate and energy policy after the Coalition's historic election defeat. Scientists warn just three years remain for the world to keep global warming below the vital 1.5°C threshold.

articles.title: Around 720 Million Years Ago, Our Planet Turned Into A Snowball Earth – Is This Why?
articles.author: Tom Hale
articles.summary: A new study claims that an ancient volcano in the Canadian Arctic triggered a climate event called Snowball Earth 720 million years ago. It is one of the most extreme and mysterious climate episodes in Earth's history. It's still unknown when exactly it occurred and how long it lasted.

articles.title: Singapore faces medium risk of severe transboundary haze in 2025: Report
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Singapore faces a higher risk of severe haze for the rest of this year compared with last year. The Singapore Institute of International Affairs has given the risk an amber rating. It cited a rise in Indonesia's deforestation as a reason for the rise in transboundary haze.

articles.title: Portugal supported by Spain in fighting major wildfires
articles.author: AFP with RTL Infos
articles.summary: More than 250 Portuguese firefighters and four Spanish aircraft are battling a major wildfire in a remote mountainous area near their border. The fire has been burning since Saturday in the Ponte da Barca area of northern Portugal's Viana do Castelo district. One firefighter has sustained minor injuries. Large parts of northern and southern Portugal remain under maximum wildfire alert.

articles.title: Natural Forces Drove 2023 Warming Spike, Not Human Emissions
articles.author: Thomas Richard
articles.summary: By mid-2023, global temperatures had gotten warmer globally by 0.5°C compared to 2022. This led to a new record for the year 2024. The rise in global temperatures occurred simultaneously with the El Niño. Honga Tonga volcano erupted at the end of January 2022. In September 2023, an additional warming of 0.58°C was detected compared to the average for 2022.

articles.title: Smoke signals: Inside the 25 July Guardian Weekly
articles.author: Isobel Montgomery
articles.summary: The 30th UN climate summit is taking place in Brazil in November. The bulk of greenhouse gas emissions come from countries that are not democratic. Christopher Nolan's new epic, The Odyssey, saw its first Imax tickets sell out in minutes. Steven Poole argues that it's time to ban opinion polls.

articles.title: Tinubu symphatises with Yola flood disaster, Niger boat mishap victims
articles.author: Abdullahi M Gulloma
articles.summary: President Bola Ahmed Tinubu mourns the loss of lives in the recent flood disaster in Yola, Adamawa state and the boat mishap in Guni village, Niger state. He commends the bravery of Adamawa and Niger States' Emergency Management Agencies, local divers, volunteers, and community leaders assisting in search and recovery efforts. He urges citizens using the waterways to ensure strict adherence to safety measures advocated by the regulatory authorities.

articles.title: Climate crisis is a public health emergency
articles.summary: The world is warming and climate change directly threatens human health. Few medical schools in Korea teach climate change as a core competency. The health care sector is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions. The United States has the highest per capita healthcare-related emissions per person, whereas Korea has a higher average healthy life expectancy.

articles.title: Climate change significantly worsened deadly 2022 Durban floods, study shows
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Climate change significantly worsened deadly 2022 Durban floods, according to a study by Phys.org and others. The study was published in the journal, "Phenomenon".       in "The Global Warming of Substances and Their Interactions with Extinctions".

articles.title: President Xi Jinping urges all-out efforts to safeguard people's lives amid floods
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged all-out efforts to ensure the safety of people's lives and property in the fight against floods and geological disasters caused by heavy rainfalls that are currently affecting some parts of China. Premier Li Qiang has urged national flood control authorities to help local governments strengthen response.

articles.title: Finland sees 30-degree temps for 17th day in a row
articles.author: Yle News
articles.summary: The temperature in Lieksa, North Karelia, Finland, reached 30.1 degrees Celsius on Monday. It is the 17th consecutive day that the temperature has breached the 30-degree-Celsius mark in Finland. The ongoing heatwave shows no sign of dissipating anytime soon.

articles.title: Iona has rapidly strengthened into a hurricane in the central Pacific Ocean, forecasters say
articles.summary: Iona has rapidly strengthened into a hurricane in the central Pacific Ocean, forecasters say. It's expected to get stronger.    iona is a Category 4 hurricane now. It is expected to strengthen to a Category 5 hurricane later.  It is in the Pacific Ocean.

articles.title: How do different generations parent differently?
articles.author: Talker Research
articles.summary: There will be scattered thunderstorms during the evening, then partly cloudy after midnight. It will be muggy and hot with a high of 95F. Winds will be NNW at 10 to 15 miles per hour. Chance of rain is 40%. The weather is hot and humid.

articles.title: No yolk: Eating eggs lowers levels of ‘bad' cholesterol
articles.author: Talker News
articles.summary: There will be scattered thunderstorms during the evening, then partly cloudy after midnight. It will be muggy and hot with a high of 95F. Winds will be NNW at 10 to 15 miles per hour. Chance of rain is 40%. The weather is hot and humid.

articles.title: Extreme weather affects mental health: what vulnerable women in Kenya told us
articles.author: Cyprian M. Mostert
articles.summary: Climatic shocks and environmental changes are one of the greatest threats to human health of the 21st century. Extreme weather can trigger mental and physical ill-health. Individuals living in poor settings and rural areas are likely to be worst hit by these climatic shocks. The site of study was the coastal Kilifi region, which is one of Kenya's poorest areas. The Kenyan government has been coordinating various stakeholders to address the impact of climate change on the next generation.

articles.title: Letter: Global warming is driven by undersea volcanoes
articles.summary: Phil Drietz has written 13 letters in Duluth News Tribune since March 23, 2023, giving reasons why manmade climate change is fake science. IPCC has been fudging the data regarding the increase of solar radiation absorption by the planet. Global warming is driven by under-sea volcanoes, hot, 40,000-mile-long mid-ocean mountain ridges and rifts, ocean currents and sunlight penetrating Earth's surface.

articles.title: Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia face a medium risk of severe haze in 2025, says report
articles.summary: Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia face a moderate risk of a severe transboundary haze occurrence for the remainder of the year, according to the Singapore Institute of International Affairs. The report points towards a surge in hotspots and smoke haze across parts of Sumatra in mid-July this year.

articles.title: UAE expresses condolences to Philippines over Typhoon Co-May victims
articles.author: Khaleej Times Staff
articles.summary: Typhoon Co-May brought heavy rainfall and battered Luzon Island, resulting in multiple deaths, injuries and widespread damage. At least 25 people have died as of 6am Friday (July 25) due to the combined impact of the southwest monsoon, and three other tropical cyclones. Floodwaters from relentless rains brought the capital Manila to a standstill earlier this week.

articles.title: Cities Vs. Climate Change: Global Exhibition In Paris Inspires Action
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: From Paris to Belém: 10 years of Global Climate Action celebrates a decade of bold urban responses to climate change since the 2015 Paris Agreement and celebrates the Paris Agreement on Climate Change in Paris and in Belémia.    .   "The Paris Agreement" was signed in 2015.

articles.title: Alaska governor allows bills on fishing and accounting to become laws
articles.author: James Brooks Alaska Beacon
articles.summary: The Alaska State Capitol is seen in partial morning sun on May 10, 2024, as seen by Claire Stremple/Alaska Beacon. The Capitol will be illuminated by the sun at that time. The sun will be visible in the morning sun by then.

articles.title: Why seagulls are flocking to the rooftops of Portland
articles.author: Katie Delaney
articles.summary: Noah Perlut is studying why seagulls are choosing city buildings over islands to nest and raise their young in Portland, Maine. He's banding the birds and tracking their movements to learn why they've chosen to nest in the heart of the city. His research shows that their breeding is just as successful on rooftops as on islands.

articles.title: Forests are sucking up much less carbon
articles.author: Ben Geman
articles.summary: In typical years, forests absorb about 30% of CO2 emissions from burning fossil fuels, but the last few years have been very different. The "sink" effect in 2023 was the lowest in over two decades and grew only slightly last year. The surge in fires released over 4 billion tons of greenhouse gases in both 2023 and 2024.

articles.title: Governor JB Pritzker continues the narrative against Texas' plan on redistricting
articles.author: Npr Illinois
articles.summary: The Illinois Department of Transportation is seeking feedback on a rural expressway from the Metro East to southern Illinois. The governor of Illinois urges Democrats to keep an eye on the redistricting effort in Texas. The message of introducing babies to peanuts early is not getting to all parents.

articles.title: ‘Silent killer': Taxpayer media finds ‘burning wood' a threat to your health
articles.summary: Paul Murray discusses how taxpayer-funded media has found wood heater pollution as a "silent killer" in Australia. He warns that if you are currently warming in an Australian winter with wood, either behind the glass or in the heater, you are part of the problem.

articles.title: ‘Morally superior': Lefties call for sacrifices on Australia's road to net zero
articles.summary: Paul Murray is on tonight's episode of Paul Murray Live. He discusses climate change, farmers enduring weather, US politics and more. He points out that Australia is only one per cent of the world's problem, while China can replace the entire Australian pollution problem in just 16 days.

articles.title: Vietnam continues to play greater role in ASEAN's development process: Australian Ambassador
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Vietnam was admitted to ASEAN in 1995. It is 30 years since then that Vietnam has become an increasingly influential and active voice within the bloc. Australia is the oldest and most important dialogue partner of the bloc and values Vietnam's active participation and support across all the fields.

articles.title: Climate Change: How Human Activity Is Creating New Seasons And Changing Nature's Calendar
articles.author: Divya Danu
articles.summary: Human actions like deforestation and climate change are creating new seasons, like haze and trash seasons, while traditional ones are vanishing. These changes disrupt nature's rhythms and challenge how we understand and live with time. Divya Danu's writing is driven by reason, shaped by curiosity, and balanced with just the right amount of skepticism.

articles.title: How Fossil Fuels Powered the Greatest Leap in Human Progress
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: Fossil fuels are the reason billions of people are alive and thriving today. They power water purification, sanitation infrastructure, refrigeration, antibiotics, heating and cooling systems, plastics for sterile hospitals, transportation for vaccines, and the Haber-Bosch process that unlocked synthetic fertilizer more than doubled human life expectancy worldwide.

articles.title: Most Aussies Fear Travel Bill, Optus Offers Roaming Tips
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A staggering 82% of Australians have experienced or fear experiencing bill shock from unexpected roaming charges when travelling overseas, according to new research commissioned by Optus. The research was carried out by the company's research arm, Optus Global Research.   .

articles.title: 4 bridges over Welland Canal temporarily closed this week
articles.author: Welland Tribune staff
articles.summary: The Glendale Avenue Bridge in St. Catharines will be closed 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., Friday for maintenance. There is a Heat Warning from MON 5:27 AM EDT until WED 12:00 AM EDT. St.Catharines Standard file photo flag wire is false flag sponsored.

articles.title: Four bridges over Welland Canal temporarily closed this week
articles.author: Welland Tribune staff
articles.summary: The Glendale Avenue Bridge in St. Catharines will be closed from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., Friday for maintenance. There is a Heat Warning from MON 5:27 AM EDT until WED 12:00 AM EDT. St.Catharines Standard file photo flag is false flag sponsored.

articles.title: Greece and Turkey wildfires: Is it safe to travel to popular holiday hotspots?
articles.author: Simon Calder
articles.summary: Greece and Turkey are experiencing a severe heatwave. Fires are burning in Greece and Turkey. The highway linking Bursa to the capital Ankara is closed as the surrounding forests burn. Simon Calder explains the latest travel advice for people due to travel this summer.

articles.title: Experts warn drastic action may be necessary in communities along US East Coast: 'We're dealing with something completely unprecedented'
articles.author: Sam Westmoreland
articles.summary: Experts warn drastic action may be necessary in communities along US East Coast due to climate change. Emma Gildesgame, a climate adaptation scientist for The Nature Conservancy, believes it's time to start talking about managed retreat as a response to climate-induced coastal change.

articles.title: Why It's Time To Tackle The ‘Triple Threat' Of Super-Pollutants
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Recent studies show that tropospheric ozone, methane and black carbon are driving a large amount of global warming, according to the UNFCCC. The study highlights how these pollutants contribute to climate change. The UNFCC is concerned about the effects of these pollutants on global warming.

articles.title: Community Sector: Net Zero by 2035 Essential 28 July
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: 88 organisations signed a statement calling on the Australian Government to aim for net zero emissions by 2035 to reduce the harmful impacts of climate change. The government is currently deliberating its 2035 emissions reduction target. The statement and list of signatories can be seen here.

articles.title: Greece's Brutal Heat Waves Potentially Deadly for Outdoor Workers
articles.author: Achilleas Kouremenos
articles.summary: Temperatures exceeding 44C were baking Greece in late July. A street sweeper died in Barcelona during a heat wave last month and 12 other city cleaners have suffered heatstroke since. Europe and Central Asia have experienced the largest spike in excessive worker heat exposure this century. Greece requires heat-safety inspections during the summer, but the country's largest labor union is calling for year-round monitoring.

articles.title: Trump's budget takes aim at gold standard measurement of atmospheric carbon dioxide
articles.author: David Ho
articles.summary: Trump administration proposes eliminating funding for the Mauna Loa Observatory on Hawaii's Big Island. It's the site of the longest continuous CO2 measurement in the world. It provides the most direct evidence of the global increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide. President Donald Trump is a renowned climate change denier. He has proposed drastic cuts to science agencies like National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation, NASA and NOAA.

articles.title: What wildfires and extreme heat in Europe could mean for your summer holiday
articles.author: Simon Calder
articles.summary: Turkey recorded its highest temperature on record on Friday at 50.5C, or 123F. The Acropolis was closed for five hours on Sunday afternoon due to high temperatures. In Greece, firefighters are tackling wildfires in the northern suburbs of Athens and on some Greek islands. There is a pattern of wildfires and evacuations on Greek islands each summer.

articles.title: Experts issue dire warning about disturbing plan proposed by White House: 'Difficult — if not impossible — to reverse'
articles.author: Samantha Hindman
articles.summary: The National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska is home to millions of animals and a vital player in keeping the planet cool. On June 17, the Trump administration proposed opening nearly 82% of the NPR-A to oil and gas drilling. The plan would expand development from 11.7 million acres to 18.5 million acres, forever altering regions vital to the survival of Arctic caribou herds, nesting grounds for over 4.5m shorebirds, and denning sites for polar bears and wolverines.

articles.title: Heatwaves, Wildfires Mark Extreme Heat Call Anniversary
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The first anniversary of the UN Secretary-General's Call to Action on Extreme Heat is on 25 July. It coincides with intense heatwaves which are impacting many countries around the world. Nearly 100 million Americans are under heat-related warnings and advisories, including for "dangerous" heat. Extreme heat is also gripping much of North Africa and the Middle East. Mediterranean region and Balkans are enduring the third heatwave of the summer. Europe had its hottest June on record.

articles.title: World Bank's Strategic Shift: Climate, Gender, and Regional Focus
articles.author: Anna Bjerde
articles.summary: The World Bank is reinforcing its commitment to the Pacific by addressing climate change and gender equality. Anna Bjerde, managing director of operations, emphasized the concerns of Pacific nations regarding food security, escalating debt, and climate-related vulnerabilities. She announced the relocation of key World Bank officials closer to Pacific region to oversee a significantly expanded $3.4 billion aid program.

articles.title: Hunger must never be 'weapon of war': UN chief
articles.author: LBC International
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres urges the international community to reject hunger as a weapon of war. Climate change is disrupting harvests, supply chains and humanitarian aid, he says. Conflict continues to spread hunger from Gaza to Sudan and beyond, he adds.

articles.title: 2024 sets new temperature record in Taiwan at 24.6°C average: CWA
articles.author: Enditem/AW
articles.summary: Taiwan's average temperature in 2024 reached 24.6 degrees Celsius, 0.7°C above the historical norm. Central Weather Administration attributed the high temperature to global warming and the El Niño phenomenon. All 22 weather stations across Taiwan recorded temperatures above the 30-year climate average. Hsinchu, Taichung, Sun Moon Lake in Nantou, Tainan, Chenggong and Taitung set new all-time temperature records. Taipei recorded 63 hot days, the most in the country.

articles.title: Deadly wildfires force thousands to evacuate in Turkey and Greece
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: High winds and soaring temperatures have hampered firefighters fighting the fires. The fires have killed at least 17 people. The temperature hit a record high of 122.9 degrees last week, which has hampered firefighters' efforts to fight the fires, which have killed 17 people so far.

articles.title: New Study Spotlights a Drying Planet, Driven by Disappearing Groundwater — What You Should Know
articles.author: Propublica Is An Independent
articles.summary: The continents are drying out and the earth's freshwater resources are under threat, according to a study based on 20 years of NASA satellite data. Nearly 6 billion people live in 101 countries facing a net decline in water supply, posing a 'critical, emerging threat to humanity'. Groundwater loss accounts for 68% of the drying in those places. The parts of the world drying most acutely are becoming interconnected.

articles.title: East Lothian residents asked to help shape long-term coastal plan
articles.author: Alex Chisholm
articles.summary: East Lothian Council is developing a Coastal Change Adaptation Plan to address future risks along the coastline, including erosion, flooding, rising sea levels and wave overtopping. Residents and stakeholders are invited to submit their observations and experiences related to coastal change. The second phase of the project is expected to begin in early 2026.

articles.title: Nigeria not immune to earthquakes, scientist warns
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: A scientist based in Uyo, Akwa Ibom State, Dr Anietie Ikott, has warned that Nigeria may soon experience a devastating earthquake and other climate change-induced disasters. He made the remarks on Saturday at a conference in Uyyo.

articles.title: UN Climate Chief Urges Resolution in Australia-Turkey COP31 Host Dispute
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Both Australia and Turkey refuse to give up their contention over hosting the next COP31 summit. Australia wants to co-host with the Pacific to emphasize its renewable energy transition, whereas Turkey suggests its Mediterranean venue could reduce travel emissions. Simon Stiell, executive secretary of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, commented that the deadlock is impacting summit preparations.

articles.title: Australia urged to act on deep sea mining after moratorium fails
articles.author: Linda Lopresti
articles.summary: There was no agreement on a moratorium on deep sea mining at the International Seabed Authority meeting in Jamaica last week. The ISA did agree to launch an investigation into the actions of contractors who applied for permits via the United States. Donald Trump signed an executive order to open international waters, including the Pacific, to deep-sea mining.

articles.title: Haze risk rising: Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia face medium threat in 2025, says report
articles.summary: Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia face a moderate risk of a severe transboundary haze occurrence for the remainder of the year, according to the Singapore Institute of International Affairs. The report points towards a surge in hotspots and smoke haze across parts of Sumatra in mid-July this year.

articles.title: Words on Birds: Help birds survive the heat
articles.author: Steve Grinley
articles.summary: It's very hot and humid in the summer. Humid weather is bad for birds, especially hummingbirds. People need to make sure they provide fresh water for the birds and change the water in bird baths daily. Hummingbirds need to expend more energy to search for fresher food sources.

articles.title: Antigua and Barbuda marks World Mangrove Day with a call for conservation action
articles.author: Kisean Joseph
articles.summary: The 2025 theme for EcoShores Sustainable Futures Network is 'Protecting Wetlands for Our Future'. The organization is working on sustainable development action throughout the Antigua and Barbuda. It is promoting the importance of mangroves and their protection from hurricanes and flooding. The organization recently launched eco-courses to promote sustainability awareness.

articles.title: UN chief urges Australia to aim higher as it debates climate goals
articles.author: Ottilie Mitchell
articles.summary: Simon Stiell, UN's climate chief, urges Australia to take more ambitious climate action. Australia has pledged to reduce emissions by 43% by 2030, but remains one of the world's biggest polluters per capita. A bill to overturn the nation's goal of net zero emissions by 2050 was moved by an opposition MP in parliament, and the Labor government considers a new reduction target for the next decade - 2035.

articles.title: Let's abandon the cult of Net Zero
articles.author: Matthew Ogilvie
articles.summary: Net Zero has turned an aspirational climate policy into a national suicide note written by governments unwilling to follow the fundamentals of scientific method. Net Zero is accelerating Australia's deindustrialisation. It is turning Australia from energy independence to dangerous reliance on foreign powers. The cost of mitigating climate change through Net Zero, through radical changes to our energy system, through subsidising renewables and going all-electric will cost trillions. Australia contribute a little over 1 per cent of global emissions.

articles.title: As US beekeepers lose over half their colonies, experts fear for the future
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Isaac Barnes hauls boxes of honeycomb from his hives to his truck in the heat. Bees' body temperature can be up to 15 degrees Celsius higher than the air around them. Scientists are trying to better understand the effects of climate change on managed and wild bees.

articles.title: UN climate chief urges Australia to boost emissions targets
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The United Nations' climate chief has challenged Australia to take more ambitious climate action. Australia is due to release its latest national emissions targets in September, setting out plans to decarbonise an economy built largely on fossil fuels. The mining superpower faces a 'defining moment' as it prepares new emissions targets.

articles.title: Greek Firefighters Engage 'Titanic' Wildfires Amidst Intense Blazes
articles.summary: Europe is experiencing a series of devastating wildfires, exacerbated by an intense and prolonged heatwave that has gripped the continent. Wildfires are burning in Greece, Turkey and Corfu. The situation is a stark reminder of the growing impact of climate change on weather patterns and natural disasters.

articles.title: Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia face medium risk of severe haze in 2025: Report
articles.author: Juiceapac Web Development Team
articles.summary: Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia face a moderate risk of a severe transboundary haze occurrence for the remainder of the year. The latest report marks an increase from the Singapore Institute of International Affairs's 2024 assessment. Hike in agricultural prices and the increased rate of deforestation have heightened the risk of fires and haze.

articles.title: ‘Net Zero could destroy civilisation'
articles.author: spiked
articles.summary: Matt Ridley is an author of Birds, Sex and Beauty and Viral. He joined spiked's chief political writer, Brendan O'Neill on his podcast to discuss the myth of the climate crisis, the folly of the green transition and Net Zero. He thinks it will be difficult to maintain civilisation while giving up on carbon.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine march pushback; Australia's ‘one shot' at clean energy; and the AFL's most sought-after signature
articles.author: Luca Ittimani
articles.summary: Organisers of a pro-Palestine rally have offered to delay their march across the Sydney Harbour Bridge this Sunday. Chris Minns, the premier of New South Wales, said his government would not support the protest. Ed Husic, the federal Labor MP, wants Australia to recognise Palestine. Sarah Henderson wants annual increases on student loans to be set to the lesser of the inflation rate or 3% in her proposed amendment to Labor's student debt discount bill. Nasiah Wanganeen-Milera's late performance for St Kilda confirmed he owns the most sought-after signature.

articles.title: UN Climate Chief Urges Resolution in Australia-Turkey COP31 Hosting Standoff
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Both Australia and Turkey submitted bids to host the COP31 summit last year, but neither has yielded. UN climate chief Simon Stiell is concerned the delay is counterproductive and undermines the planning process. Australia's climate change minister stated that their bid has significant backing, yet Turkey remains unyielding.

articles.title: Researchers develop game-changing system to predict major natural disasters: 'Instrumental in early warning systems'
articles.author: Cody Januszko
articles.summary: Researchers at the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology in South Korea have developed a system leveraging artificial intelligence to overcome the shortcomings of satellite data tracking sea surface temperatures. Warming waters have been linked to a range of extreme weather events, including those associated with El Niño and La Niña systems. The technology could also be instrumental in early warning systems for marine disasters.

articles.title: 'Medium risk' of severe haze as higher agricultural prices drive deforestation: Singapore researchers
articles.summary: There is a medium risk of transboundary haze affecting Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia for the rest of 2025, according to the Singapore Institute of International Affairs' yearly haze outlook report. The report is based on developments in three areas: markets, weather and policies. It comes amid reports of an escalation in hot spots and smoke haze in Sumatra in Indonesia in mid-July.

articles.title: Fiji becomes first Small Island State to launch forecast-based cyclone action plan
articles.author: fijivillage
articles.summary: Fiji is the first Small Island Developing State in the Pacific to adopt a Simplified Early Action Protocol for Tropical Cyclones. The new protocol allows humanitarian teams to release funding and take life-saving measures before a cyclone makes landfall. Fiji is among the countries most exposed to tropical cyclones, with an average of seven per season.

articles.title: Beijing Faces Torrential Downpours: A Flooded Frontier
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Beijing and nearby provinces are facing severe weather conditions as heavy rain continues, resulting in deadly landslides and missing persons. In the suburb of Miyun, flash floods have devastated numerous villages, displacing over 4,400 residents. The unrelenting rainfall has disrupted power for thousands and prompted Beijing to issue its highest flood alert. The storms are attributed to the East Asian monsoon.

articles.title: Global Gas Flaring Hits 17-Year High, Waisted US$63 Billion
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: Russia, Iran, and Iraq drive nearly half of all flaring. Nigeria and the U.S. accounted for 76%. Russia and Iran posted steady rises. Nigeria reduced volumes slightly but remained among the worst performers. World Bank-endorsed 'Zero Routine Flaring by 2030' nations cut intensity by 12%. Non-signatories increased intensity by 25%.

articles.title: Ignoring climate change is unwise because our children's lives could be at risk
articles.author: Andy Brown
articles.summary: There is mounting evidence that the climate is changing. The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has risen by 28 parts per million since 1800. The level of carbon emissions is still rising fast. It is scientifically impossible to inject that amount of extra CO2 into the air without trapping increased amounts of heat. Human civilisation has not succeeded in surviving a rapid climate change.

articles.title: Alex Graham to Head NSW National Parks Service
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Alex Graham has been appointed to lead the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) from 18 August 2025. She previously worked with City of Gold Coast Council as Executive General Manager, Environment, Heritage and Resilience. She also worked as Executive Director Landscapes, Water and Natural Capital at the Queensland Department of Environment and Science between 2017 and 2020.

articles.title: Trains stopped by grass fire in Sydney's south-west
articles.summary: Some trains are cancelled as a grass fire burns in Sydney's south-west, some in the city's south west and others in the north-west. The fire is burning in the area of the Sydney Opera House, which is south west of the city.

articles.title: Trains stopped by grass fire in Sydney's south-west
articles.summary: Some trains are cancelled as a grass fire burns in Sydney's south-west, some in the city's south west and others in the north-west. The fire is burning in the area of the Sydney Opera House, which is south west of the city.

articles.title: To numerous Muslim women in Australia, encountering Islamophobia seems unavoidable
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Dr Nora Amath, Executive Director of the Islamophobia Register, observed a 'dramatic surge' in Islamophobic incidents following the October 7th attacks in 2023. Women and girls are disproportionately affected, accounting for approximately 75% of the victims. Geopolitical events can serve as a catalyst for Islamophobia in Australia, but they're not the only contributing factor.

articles.title: Dependance Of Life On Climate
articles.summary: Climate change is a major challenge we face today. Human activities such as air pollution, deforestation, and the burning of fossil fuels are the primary contributors to climate change. Governments are working to forge international agreements and scientists developing clean energy technologies. Individuals can also make a difference by practicing energy conservation, spreading awareness, avoiding plastic, and even planting trees.

articles.title: Vital, vulnerable and vanishing: mangroves are declining rapidly
articles.author: Editorial Dept.
articles.summary: World Mangrove Day was held on July 26th. Mangroves are under threat from development, water management, erosion and sedimentation. They absorb up to 10 times more carbon than tropical rainforests, shield coastlines from erosion and storms, and serve as vital nurseries for countless marine species.

articles.title: Today's News Headlines: Israel opens airspace for Gaza aid drops
articles.summary: Sydney to expect rain from Wednesday, a train derailment has killed three people Germany and Pauline Hanson calls for an end to Net Zero policy.   .    "Pauline Hanson" is a member of the Australian National Party and a former politician.

articles.title: Barnaby Joyce wants Australia to abandon net zero - but his 4 central claims don't stack up
articles.author: Ella Vines
articles.summary: The Albanese government should not be distracted from the climate action task. Australia's next round of climate targets should be based on the best available science and make a meaningful, credible contribution to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, as well as making a meaningful contribution to climate action.

articles.title: Reducing air pollution speeding up global warming climate crisis
articles.author: Noel Nabiswa
articles.summary: 2023 and 2024 were the warmest years on record, exceeding 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels for the first time. Most of the acceleration in warming since 2010 was likely due to efforts against air pollution in East Asia. China implemented drastic air quality policies that slashed sulphur dioxide emissions by 75%.

articles.title: Severe warming could slash 45% off GDP, new study warns
articles.author: Jana  Marx
articles.summary: Climate change could cut the world's economy by 40% and SA's GDP by as much as 45% by the end of the century, according to a new study. The research was led by Dr Timothy Neal, an Australian economist and senior lecturer at the University of New South Wales. He argues that traditional economic models have underestimated climate damage by focusing only on local weather events.

articles.title: Australia's Crucial Climate Crossroads: A Call to Action
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: UN climate chief urges Australia to adopt bold emissions targets by 2035 and hasten its transition to clean energy. Stiell criticizes Australia for approving new fossil fuel projects despite its ambition to co-host the upcoming UN COP31 summit. Australia's path forward is seen as pivotal for both its economic future and regional security.

articles.title: UN climate chief warns Australia not to pick a ‘bog standard' 2035 carbon emissions target
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: UN climate chief warns Australia not to pick a 'bog standard' 2035 carbon emissions target, as the Guardian reports. The Guardian reports that UN climate chief is concerned about Australia's choice of a 2035 target for carbon emissions reduction. The newspaper reports that the target could be a "bog-standard".

articles.title: Mum's warning after son severely burned at WA holiday spot
articles.summary: Danella D'Antuoni's son Alby, 3, suffered severe burns to his feet and toes after walking on an abandoned campfire in WA's Dampier Peninsula. The fire had not been put out properly and the dirt had trapped the heat beneath the surface. Alby didn't require surgery.

articles.title: Why ICJ climate decision matters to us all
articles.author: Siobhan Mcdonnell
articles.summary: The Advisory Opinion from the International Court of Justice on the 'Obligations of States in Respect of Climate Change' is historic. It establishes clear obligations and attributions in international law. It makes clear that all states have an obligation to mitigate the impacts of carbon emissions and limit the global temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius beyond pre-industrial levels. Maintaining a '1.5-aligned' global temperature pathway is crucial for many climate-vulnerable countries, especially Pacific atoll states. Australia is yet to submit its latest, third-round NDC (NDC 3.0).

articles.title: Climate and poverty
articles.author: Abbas Nasir
articles.summary: Climate change is driving up poverty. Sub-Saharan Africa is projected to carry the heaviest burden. By 2030, climate change could leave nearly 49m people in the region in extreme poverty. Pakistan, with its large rural population and weak safety nets, is among the most at risk. Pakistan must rethink its development planning to prioritise climate resilience.

articles.title: Torrential Rains in Northern China: A Shift in Climate Patterns
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The deluge impacting northern China has intensified fears of natural disasters such as landslides and flooding. Authorities have responded by relocating over 4,000 residents as torrential rains continue to batter the northwestern suburbs of Miyun in Beijing. In nearby Shanxi province, emergency services are engaged in ongoing rescue operations amid raging floodwaters.

articles.title: CERES Satellite Data Suggests Low Climate Sensitivity
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: Willis Eschenbach used the CERES database to calculate the equilibrium climate sensitivity (ECS) to greenhouse gases. He used a 4th-order polynomial fit to the average 25-year data (16200 data points) and calculated a global average imbalance of 3.95 W/m2 per °C of surface temperature change.

articles.title: Mother issues warning after toddler walks over apparent abandoned campfire and suffers severe burns
articles.author: Molly Magennis
articles.summary: Danella D'Antuoni's son Alby suffered severe burns to his feet and toes when he walked over an abandoned campfire in WA's Dampier Peninsula. The fire had not been put out properly and the dirt had trapped the heat beneath the surface.

articles.title: Sunshine Coast Pioneers Coastal Sustainability Talks
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Sunshine Coast Council will host the 2025 Australian Coastal Councils Conference from July 31 to August 1 in Mooloolaba. It will bring together local government leaders, researchers and policy makers to share insights and strategies for managing Australia's diverse and dynamic coastal regions.

articles.title: Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia face medium risk of severe haze in 2025: report
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia face a medium risk of experiencing a severe transboundary haze event for the rest of 2025. Elevated agricultural prices and a rise in deforestation have heightened the likelihood of fires and haze. Economic and policy shifts could inadvertently drive deforestation and increase haze risk.

articles.title: UN climate chief warns Australia not to pick a ‘bog standard' 2035 carbon emissions target
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: The UN's climate chief has declared Australia's 2035 emissions target will define the country's future. Simon urged the Albanese government to go for what's smart by going big. He was speaking in Sydney on Monday, the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change executive secretary.

articles.title: Pollution, melting microbes, undamming rivers, risks for elders: 4 key climate issues (UNOG - United Nations Office at Geneva)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: There are four emerging threats that could reshape life for millions unless urgent action is taken. They are ancient microbes awakening in melting glaciers, toxic pollutants unleashed by floods, and toxic pollutants from floods. The world is increasingly shaped by climate extremes and environmental experts are delivering a blunt warning.

articles.title: UN chief urges Australia to aim higher as it debates climate goals
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Despite efforts to reduce emissions, Australia is one of the biggest polluters per capita, despite efforts to cut down on CO2 emissions. Australia has a population of 1.3 billion people. Australia is the second biggest emitter of CO2 per capita.

articles.title: Rain bomb alert as mammoth weather system moves across Australia and temperatures plunge - as ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Wet weather system stretches from the west to the east coast of Australia. Every state and territory recorded widespread rain in the past week, the most so far for the year for many. Rain and cold temperatures are expected for large parts of the country in the coming days.

articles.title: Satellites reveal a hidden global water crisis that could change life on Earth
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Earth's continents are drying at alarming rates, impacting billions and accelerating sea level rise. Four major continents are affected by the drying, according to satellite data: Antarctica, Mars, Greenland, Antarctica and the Pacific Ocean. The Earth's oceans are also getting warmer.

articles.title: Australia has seen 'dramatic surge' in Islamophobic incidents since Oct. 7, 2023
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: There has been a rise in Islamophobic incidents in Australia since Hamas attacks on Israel ignited the Gaza war. Women and girls are disproportionately targeted, according to local broadcaster SBS News. Nora Amath, executive director of the Muslim Council of Australia, is quoted in the report.

articles.title: UN Calls on Australia to Get Serious About Net Zero
articles.author: Oil Price
articles.summary: UN official urges Australia to go big on net zero and accelerate its energy transition. Australia should "go for what's smart by going big" on energy transition, UN official says.       .   "Go for what is smart"

articles.title: Storm casualties rise to 31, millions in distress—NDRRMC
articles.author: Manila Standard
articles.summary: The combined impact of tropical cyclones 'Crising' and 'Crisp' has been felt in the Pacific Ocean.    "Crising" is one of the most powerful cyclones in the world. It has made a huge impact on the ocean.

articles.title: Water scarcity in Pakistan — a geopolitical ticking time bomb
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Pakistan is facing severe urban flooding triggered by erratic and intensified rainfall events. In 2024 and 2025, the country's major cities will be lashed by record-breaking downpours overwhelming fragile drainage systems and displacing thousands. The latest wave of flooding is the result of climate change.

articles.title: Keep open beach, safeguard the climate
articles.author: File/Grace Beahm Alford/Staff
articles.summary: Officials from Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park want to rename the No Name Beach as "Fort Sumter Beach" to make it easier to treat it like part of the protected national park. The effort should be opposed by everyone in the Lowcountry who goes boating and loves to find a nice spot to relax and enjoy the water. America is constantly under siege by unprecedented floods, wildfires, hurricanes, storms, tornadoes and intense heat and humidity. The Trump administration has pulled the United States out of the international climate agreement and cut funds from the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration and the National Weather Service.

articles.title: Humpback whales lose over 36 pct body fat during annual migrations: study
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Humpback whales lose about 36 percent of their body fat during their annual migrations. The loss of 11,000 kg of body fat per adult whale during migration underscores the vital importance of Antarctic krill feeding grounds for their survival, according to scientists from Australia, United States, Colombia and Denmark.

articles.title: How to scale private finance for adaptation and unlock new business opportunities (ICC - International Chamber of Commerce)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Adaptation must play a central role in securing resilience, according to the new ICC-commissioned Oxera report. The report assesses the impact of climate change on the world's economies and the environment. It will be released on 28 July 2025.

articles.title: Author's Tranquility Press Presents a Powerful Call to Wonder: A Backyard's Story of a Changing Climate
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: Frederic Buse charts 50 years of climate change trends in his new release. He charts One Note, One Birdsong, One Bloom at a Time, and "Trends Due to Climate Change" by Frederic Buse. Buse's music is lyrical and revelatory.

articles.title: Greenpeace, civil society groups demand urgent action for making MSC pay for environment damage, livelihood loss
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: A White Paper outlines the potential ecological and socio-economic impacts of the shipwreck that occurred 14.6. It is based on the findings of a report by the World Resources Institute (WRI). WRI is concerned about the impact of the wreck on the environment.

articles.title: Governor Kundi highlights urgent need for local climate action
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Governor of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Faisal Karim Kundi, has said that climate change is not only a global issue but also an urgent local concern. He said that the phenomenon is not merely a scientific problem, but a social problem.

articles.title: What Happens If The Arctic Permafrost Melts?
articles.author: BGR
articles.summary: Permafrost is the melting of the permafrost. Here are some key things you should know about it and the consequences if it melts. It's very important to know what it does and what it could do to you if it does melt.

articles.title: Islamophobia Incidents Increase in Australia
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: There has been a rise in Islamophobic incidents in Australia since the cross-border attacks by Hamas on Israel on October 7, 2023. This escalated the situation in the Gaza.    -Menaafn.org.uk. The increase is due to the attacks by the Palestinian group Hamas.

articles.title: Forests Are Sucking Up Much Less Carbon Today
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: Forests are sucking up less carbon today. In typical years, forests and other vegetation suck up roughly 30% of emissions from burning fossil fuels. In recent years, the power of the world's forests to check the growth of planet-warming emissions has weakened.

articles.title: China Fires Back at US Allies: 'Political Manipulation'-
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: British and Australian officials have blasted China over a range of grievances, from Hong Kong to the South China Sea, including the issue of Hong Kong and the South Pacific Sea.      Â   in Chinese.  in British and Australian media.

articles.title: Challenges in climate policy implementation
articles.author: Atiq Rahman
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the most vulnerable countries to the impact of global climate change. The country has formulated a set of policies, plans and strategies to address climate change through adaptation, mitigation and disaster risks reduction. The forthcoming COP-30 will have a key focus on global climate governance. The government has formulated the Bangladesh climate change Gender Action Plan.
